title: If my girlfriend live with me more than 2 years, does she get half of my assets?
question: my girlfriend lives with me in my house for more than 2 years, she never was married and doesn't have a kids. Does she gets half of my assets?
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Community property in divorce,Divorce and bankruptcy,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Divorce and family,Filing a lawsuit,Family law,Domestic relationships,Marriage,Common-law marriage
answers:
No, California is a community property state. You would need to be married for community property laws to kick in. Any assets or debts accrued after the date of marriage, but before the date of separation belong to the marriage and upon dissolution are divisible by one-half to each party.

Since you are not married, no community interested has developed. Your girlfriend is not entitled to one-half of your assets.

While California does not recognize "common law" marriages (where an unmarried couple has lived together so long that the state considers them to be married), do be careful about holding yourself out as married, or making promises to support your girlfriend, as that could create liability for you to support her after a break-up.

If she has contributed to any assets or debts (ex. she contributed to the downpayment on a house), she would be entitled to recoup that interest--though, if necessary, any litigation would take place in the general civil courts, as opposed to the family law courts.

No, there is no such thing as common law marriage in CA regardless of how long you lived together.

Unless you deeded her an interest in the property, she should not have any interest in the property. The only way she could acquire interest in the property is if you sign an agreement with her in exchange for whatever services she is providing you agreed to give her an interest in the property. Otherwise, in regard to her, no dice.

No. Community property laws only kick-in once you are married. However, as counsel sates you are not entitled to keep certain things if you start co-mingling funds. If there is a specific thing you are worried about, you should be a bit more specific. Your best option is to keep all funds separate, and pay for living expenses equally. Do not hold yourself out as married though, otherwise you may wind up having to defend a "putative spouse" claim. Something that I have seen many people try to claim, only to be defeated after hearing that could cost thousands of dollars.

California is a community property state and you have to be married for community property to be divided. California does not have common law marriage, so any division of property would be based on other law. If she put money into a property you certainly would not be able to be enriched unjustly.
